content: Commercial real estate owners paid off maturing loans at a slower rate in May as they found it harder to refinance their buildings, according to Morningstar Credit Ratings LLC.There were 790 loans that had been repackaged into commercial mortgage backed securities that came due in May, with a total unpaid balance of $9.4 billion. Of those, landlords repaid 64.9% in the six months leading up to their maturity dates. That compares with payoff rates of 71.5% in April and the low-to-mid 80% range last year, Morningstar said.Meanwhile, the number of owners who have failed to repay their loans on time or are delinquent on monthly payments has been rising. Over the past 12 months, the percentage of delinquent commercial mortgage securities loans at maturity averaged 17.8%. That was up from 10% in the June 2015 to April 2016 period, the rating agency said.Loan repayment performance has been weakening partly because in 2007 there was a record volume of 10-year commercial property loans converted into mortgage securities. The real-estate industry for several years has been bracing itself for the so-called wall of maturities that was going to hit this year as a result.“It’s all because of the riskier nature of the loans originated 10 years ago,” said       Steve Jellinek,        a Morningstar vice president. “Today, with more conservative lending standards, they can’t get refinancing.”The wall of maturity hasn’t hit as hard as many had feared earlier this year partly because debt funds and a wide range of other nontraditional lenders became more active in commercial real estate. But some of those lenders now “are taking a step back” and making refinancing harder for property owners holding riskier loans, Mr. Jellinek said.Owners of some retail properties are having a particularly difficult time obtaining refinancing because online retail has eroded their rents and occupancy rates. Also, suburban office buildings have a higher rate of default than some other property types because of the growing shift of employers to downtowns preferred by millennials, Mr. Jellinek said.Write to Peter Grant at peter.grant@wsj.com
news_title: Commercial Mortgage Borrowers Finding It Harder to Pay Debts

content: New YorkBefore turning to the controversies inspired by the Public Theater’s new production of       Shakespeare’s       “      Julius Caesar      ” at Central Park’s Delacorte Theater, consider what makes the title character such a tyrant. The evidence is strangely scant. We hear from Brutus that he was ambitious. He valued theatrical display as a political tool. And while boasting of being as constant as the Northern Star, he inconsistently gave into whim and superstition.Julius CaesarThe Public Theater, Delacorte Theater, Central Park  Free, 212-539-8500, closes June 18.Be that as it may, fearsome tyrant he is taken to be. But in this production, the real tyrant is not Caesar, but its director,       Oskar Eustis.       He more clearly comes across as ambitious, inconsistent, with little regard for limits, manipulating his audience by playing to popular taste. Perhaps, given such directorial tyranny, I might follow the example of the play’s conspirators, justly take dagger in hand, and add a bloody gouge to his self-inflicted wounds.If that idea seems rather tasteless, is it any more so than       Gregg Henry,        as Caesar, impersonating not a Roman tyrant but President       Donald Trump      ? Or       Tina Benko,        as Caesar’s wife, Calpurnia, appearing as a slinky model with a Slavic accent meant to suggest       Melania Trump       (though Ms. Benko sounds more like a Transylvanian Israeli)?Maybe every director is entitled to some political posturing, particularly with Shakespeare who, like       Bach,        can take a lot of interpretive abuse before he becomes something else. But Mr. Eustis’s territorial claims are imperial. In the program notes, he boasts: “I can say without embarrassment that I decided to open our summer season with Julius Caesar as of November 9, 2016.” In other words, he saw Trump as Caesar the day after Election Day, he thinks that point of view is self-evident, and he still sees the analogy.Let’s say he’s correct. So when Caesar emerges from a bathtub in this production, stark naked and displaying himself for conspirators and audience alike, no doubt we are meant to think of Trumpian narcissism. What then are we to think of when this erstwhile president is lying in a puddle of blood in the Roman Senate?Ay, there’s the rub. It is not surprising that Delta Air Lines and Bank of America announced they were pulling out of sponsorship of the production.But, given Mr. Eustis’s political perspective, such corporate opposition must be like the coronet Caesar covets. It is an honor, which increases because he finds it so wrong-headed. He has said the play is really a “warning parable” about the dangers of fighting for democracy using undemocratic means. Brutus and Cassius come to no good. The play opposes assassination; it does not glorify it.That, at least, is Mr. Eustis’s claim. But Shakespeare doesn’t really argue that point. Neither does Mr. Eustis’s staging, really; he makes it clear who the bad guys are: Caesar’s men, wearing Big Brother-like Eye insignias on their flak jackets. The good guys are the conspirators and protesters, who are also responsible for mounting the spontaneous-seeming public memorial we see on arriving, looking like those that arose after the 9/11 attacks, this one supposedly mounted in memory of Pompey, just killed by (terrorist) Caesar.Audience members even go on stage to scrawl comments on protest posters proclaiming “Resist”—which, at the play’s beginning, are quickly pasted over by Caesar’s fascistic police. Lest we miss the point, Cassius appears at Brutus’ door wearing a pussy hat.The play grossly overstates Caesar’s tyranny in order to justify the assassination. And then how does Mr. Eustis demonstrate the “warning parable”? He doesn’t. Near the play’s end, Caesarian riot police shoot into a presumably democratic, unarmed crowd of protesters. Ideology trumps all. The production even indulges in “intersectionality”—a form of 21st-century conceptual imperialism in which every imagined victim is said to share similar political oppressors. Thus,       Marc Antony       is cast as a woman (      Elizabeth Marvel      ), leading to pronoun changes throughout and inspiring a dollop of sympathetic ambiguity (though we give this gender-indulgence up when she ultimately displays bad-guy brutishness). As for the poet Cinna, who is set upon in the street by a maddened populace, here, to suit the director’s pre-packaged prejudices, he is a Muslim pummeled to death by Caesar’s police.Thus is self-righteous directorial tyranny exercised, leading to any number of incompatibilities. But what about Shakespeare? He was interested in something far more subtle in 1599, when this play was first performed. Tyranny is not his subject, which is why we see so little of it. He was exploring—as he was in other plays—the evolving tensions between populism and patrician heritage, between the nascent idea of a populace and the fading idea of republican nobility. The public is reckless and fickle. But it is also an authority to which government is beginning to appeal, not just for approval but for legitimacy. Cassius—played by       John Douglas Thompson,        who thankfully dominates this production with his clarity and vitality—understands this better than Brutus (      Corey Stoll      ), who reasons with old-school ineffectuality, calling on honorable notions of behavior and virtue. There are reasons why, throughout the play, characters wonder about the time or the hour: The world is in an uneasy state of transition.Such themes don’t fit easily with Mr. Eustis’s grade-school notions. But they are far more intriguing than the tyrannical vision he crudely enforces in their place.—Mr. Rothstein is the Journal’s Critic at Large.Appeared in the June 14, 2017, print edition as '‘Caesar’: A Tyrant in the Director’s Chair CAESAR.'
news_title: ‘Julius Caesar’ Review: A Tyrant in the Director’s Chair

content: Pacific Investment Management Co. President       Jay Jacobs,        a onetime candidate to run the giant money manager, will retire in September.The firm said Tuesday it would shift Mr. Jacobs’ responsibilities to longtime Pimco executives       Robin Shanahan       and       Peter Strelow,        who become co-chief operating officers. Ms. Shanahan is head of human resources, while Mr. Strelow serves as chief administrative officer.The moves are the biggest management changes Pimco Chief Executive       Emmanuel Roman       has made since he joined the firm last fall. Mr. Roman is trying to move the firm past a 2014 split with co-founder       Bill Gross       that led to an exodus of client money, sagging morale and a distracting legal battle.Pimco reversed an extended period of outflows in the second half of last year, and ran its streak to three straight quarters of net inflows in early 2017. In March, Pimco settled a breach-of-contract lawsuit from Mr. Gross for $81 million.Mr. Jacobs’s departure will end a 19-year career with Pimco. The 46-year-old executive managed many of the firm’s internal functions, and often served as a counselor to employees grappling with Pimco’s culture and post-Gross malaise, current and former executives said. As the firm’s outlook brightened in recent months, Mr. Jacobs said he determined it was time to step away.“The firm is absolutely back on track and you’ve seen that in the numbers so far,” Mr. Jacobs said. “I’m really going to miss my Pimco colleagues, but the firm is in a great place.”Mr. Jacobs joined Pimco in 1998 and was head of its Munich office and human resources before becoming president.When former CEO Mohamed El-Erian left the firm in early 2014, Mr. Jacobs offered to interview for the role, people familiar with the matter said. He did so, one of these people said, at the behest of other top Pimco figures who were concerned because only one senior executive.       Douglas Hodge,        had sought the post.Mr. Hodge was named CEO, but Pimco appointed Mr. Jacobs its president, and put him on equal footing with Mr. Hodge in new organizational chart.Last year, Pimco executives and money managers began to weigh whether the firm needed outside executives to help navigate some of the sweeping changes under way in the asset-management industry. Mr. Jacobs was among those advocating for an external search, and led that process along with investment chief       Daniel Ivascyn,        the people said.He plans to join Georgetown University’s Center for Financial Markets and Policy in January as fellow. He will remain at Pimco as an adviser until at least September 2018, the firm said.Write to Justin Baer at justin.baer@wsj.comAppeared in the June 14, 2017, print edition as 'Pimco President Jacobs Is Retiring.'
news_title: Pimco Says President Jay Jacobs to Retire, Appoints Two Co-Operating Chiefs

content: Puerto Rico’s governor said he would travel to Washington this week to lobby Congress to recognize the U.S. territory’s vote in favor of becoming the 51st state, even if it means surrendering its newfound debt-restructuring powers.Despite boycotts by opposition parties that depressed voter turnout, Puerto Rican voters delivered “a clear rejection of the current colonial status and a path forward through statehood,” Gov. Ricardo Rosselló said in an interview with The Wall Street Journal.Voters opted for U.S. statehood by a 97% margin in Sunday’s vote, though turnout was just 23% as opponents of the governor urged their constituents to snub the vote. The last time Puerto Rico called a plebiscite on its political status, in 2012, 78% of voters turned out.The results aren’t binding on Congress, which must approve any change in Puerto Rico’s political status.The vote also took place without approval from the Justice Department, which had earlier raised objections to the governor’s proposed ballot language. He said he would attempt to convince members of Congress that the 3.4 million island residents had nonetheless supplied a mandate in favor of becoming the 51st state.“The rules that have always applied are, those who go to the ballot box determine the outcome,” Gov. Rosselló said.U.S. lawmakers, who have historically been skeptical of accepting Puerto Rico as a state, are especially loathe to do so now with the territory grappling with a financial crisis that is stifling its economy and elevating rates of poverty and joblessness, said Amilcar Antonio Barreto, a professor at Northeastern University.Congress has historically favored keeping the territorial status quo “because it’s the constitutional arrangement that gives them maximum flexibility over Puerto Rican affairs,” he said.Lawmakers last year passed a rescue package to install a federal financial oversight board with a mandate to get Puerto Rico’s yawning budget gaps under control and tackle its $73 billion mountain of debt.While many U.S. municipalities can restructure their obligations under chapter 9 of the U.S. bankruptcy code, U.S. states don’t have a similar restructuring option to deal with a potential default on their general obligations. The Puerto Rico rescue law, however, gave the oversight board authority to adjust debts obligations in ways the states can’t.Mr. Rosselló said that making Puerto Rico the 51st state would lead to dramatic growth “as the natural reaction of a stronger economy impacting a smaller one,” removing the need for those restructuring powers.“This economic growth would allow us to be able to service our debt adequately even without the tools provided in Promesa,” he said, referring to the Puerto Rico Oversight, Management, and Economic Stability Act, which established a process for restructuring debt. “Our debt is simply a symptom of a much greater problem which is our economy.”A national television advertisement released by a pro-statehood group on Tuesday echoed those themes, saying that statehood “benefits all Americans, ends corporate tax breaks and enables Puerto Rico to compete, prosper and pay its fair share on equal footing.”The oversight board last month placed Puerto Rico under what amounts to the largest-ever U.S. municipal bankruptcy. Its delay in approving a $9 billion restructuring deal covering the island power utility has rankled Republicans in Congress who viewed the agreement as a road map toward consensual settlements of Puerto Rico’s other debts.Write to Andrew Scurria at Andrew.Scurria@wsj.com

content: Years ago an acquaintance spent several hair-raising months as a bodyguard for Angus Young, who plays guitar for a rowdy musical troupe called AC/DC. The job required the acquaintance to occasionally assert himself in a saloon scuffle. He brought to this task a particular insight, which he later shared with your humble correspondent: “The problem most guys have in bar fights is that they think there are rules. There are no rules.”A sensible general rule is to run away from the bar instead of fighting, though it’s clear this rule is problematic if you have contracted to protect one of the patrons.In contemporary Washington, it seems that residents increasingly favor political combat without any rules at all. This column isn’t so much addressing formal written rules, but the courtesies and customs that help make a democracy go.Many Democrats seem to have decided that the Trump presidency is uniquely undeserving of respect. On Saturday Salon.com enthusiastically described one legislator losing her composure:Mr. Trump has previously inspired profane responses from other Democratic officials and of course from demonstrators wearing hats named for genitalia who staged a protest in Washington on his first full day in office. CNN noted in April that “profane clips have become routine in Democratic National Committee Chairman       Tom Perez’s       speeches.”Not profane but unusual was Monday’s spectacle of a Senate minority leader crafting a homemade video parody of the President’s cabinet meeting. And of course back in Leader Chuck Schumer’s hometown of New York City, the President’s adversaries have been expressing their views through a different medium. According to the Washington Post:It appeared that the President was being insulted again this week amid a series of tweets claiming that the Golden State Warriors, fresh off their latest NBA championship, had decided to skip the traditional White House visit. This turned out to be fake news, according to the Charlotte Observer, which quotes the team saying they have not decided what to do in the event they are invited.Mr. Trump for his part certainly didn’t stick to the normal rules of political decorum when he campaigned for the office, so one could argue that he is partly responsible. Some might even say that Mr. Trump over the years has been a lot like the music of AC/DC: high-energy with coarse lyrics.Perhaps not as coarse but more potentially destructive to the republic has been the disrespect former FBI Director       James Comey       has shown for those on both sides of the aisle. Though never appointed to the bench, he assigned himself the task of rendering judgments on other public officials.And Mr. Comey has something in common with all of Mr. Trump’s other critics—he is not the duly elected President of the United States. Perhaps Mr. Trump’s critics will reflect on this fact and consider that, even if they don’t respect him, they ought to respect the judgment of the people who chose him.***Bottom Stories of the DayStill Leading from Behind  “U.S. leads the way in obesity; third of the world overweight: report,” New Orleans Times-Picayune, June 12Maximum Clinton Donors: Where Are They Now?  “Special counsel team members donated to Dems, FEC records show,” CNN, June 13Maybe He Could Be Persuaded to Move to Washington  “Moving to Texas? Justice Don Willett has some tips,” Austin American-Statesman, June 12Was She Expecting Loyalty?  “Comey’s second confrontation with the former attorney general ended in ‘steely silence’,” WJLA, June 13Another Underreported Success in American Education  “Two Vermont colleges switch to ‘university’ to attract Chinese students,” China Daily, June 12The Lonely Lives of Water Officials  “Nation’s water officials converge on Philly, seeking a closer public embrace,” Philadelphia Inquirer, June 12Question and AnswerRebounding with Rodman  “UVA student who was imprisoned for 17 months in North Korea is airlifted back to America still in a COMA ‘after he caught botulism in custody’ - just hours after Denis Rodman lands in the country,” Daily Mail, June 13***Note to readers: The existence of Myles Pollin has been confirmed.***Follow James Freeman on Twitter.Subscribe to the Best of the Web email with one click.To suggest items, please email best@wsj.com.(Carol Muller helps compile Best of the Web. content: U.S. crude-oil stocks are expected to show a decrease in data due Wednesday from the Department of Energy, according to a survey of analysts and traders by The Wall Street Journal.Estimates from 12 analysts and traders surveyed showed that U.S. oil inventories are projected to have decreased by 2.6 million barrels, on average, in the week ended June 9.All 12 expect stockpiles to shrink. Forecasts range from a decrease of 4.3 million barrels to a decrease of 1 million barrels. The closely watched survey from the Energy Information Administration is due at 10:30 a.m. EDT Wednesday.Gasoline stockpiles are expected to show a decrease of 700,000 barrels, on average, according to analysts. Nine expect them to fall and three expect them to rise. Estimates range from a drop of 2.5 million barrels to an increase of 2 million barrels.Stocks of distillates, which include heating oil and diesel, are expected to grow by 600,000 million barrels. Nine analysts expect an increase and three expect a decline. Forecasts range from a decline of 1.5 million barrels to an increase of 2.6 million barrels.Refinery use is seen falling 0.2 percentage point to 93.9% of capacity, based on EIA data. Six analysts expect a decrease, three expect an increase and three didn’t report expectations. Forecasts range from a fall of 1 percentage point to a rise of 0.5 point.The American Petroleum Institute, an industry group, said late Tuesday that its own data for the week showed a 2.8-million-barrel increase in crude supplies, a 1.8-million-barrel rise in gasoline stocks and a 1.5-million-barrel decrease in distillate inventories, according to a market participant.Write to Alison Sider at alison@sider@wsj.com(END) Dow Jones NewswiresJune 13, 2017 16:53 ET (20:53 GMT)Copyright (c) 2017 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.Write to Alison Sider at alison.sider@wsj.com

content: The White House pushed back on suggestions that President Donald Trump has considered firing special counsel Robert Mueller, amid a chorus of Republican warnings that it would be a mistake to oust the man leading the investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 elections.For days, allies of Mr. Trump have been questioning Mr. Mueller’s independence and the need for a special counsel. But the issue escalated on Monday when a friend of the president and Chief Executive of Newsmax Media, Chris Ruddy, gave a television interview in which he said Mr. Trump is considering firing Mr. Mueller.Both White House aides and a senior Justice Department official on Tuesday played down the notion that Mr. Mueller is on shaky ground or could even be dismissed so readily. The White House noted that Mr. Ruddy hasn’t spoken to the president about Mr. Mueller’s role.One White House official said that Mr. Mueller’s dismissal “is not something that is being discussed internally,” adding Mr. Ruddy appeared to be “speculating.”Asked if he believed Mr. Trump was poised to dismiss Mr. Mueller,       Newt Gingrich,        a former Republican House speaker who is in contact with the president and says he spoke to him Monday night, said: “No, I don’t think so.”Mr. Ruddy, in an interview Tuesday, stood by his remarks. He was at the White House on Monday but did not meet with the president.Mr. Ruddy said that he has spoken to a half dozen people over the past month “familiar with the president’s thinking” who confirmed that Mr. Trump sees firing Mr. Mueller as an “option” that is “under serious consideration.”The deputy attorney general,       Rod Rosenstein,        is the only one with authority to fire Mr. Mueller. Under Justice Department rules, he could only do so for cause. On Tuesday, Mr. Rosenstein testified on Capitol Hill that he wouldn’t follow any White House order to fire Mr. Mueller unless there was a legal and appropriate reason. If he chose, Mr. Trump could then fire Mr. Rosenstein, but there are only a few other senior Trump administration officials currently serving within the department and it is unclear if they would follow such orders either.Mr. Rosenstein added that he was “confident” that Mr. Mueller will have “sufficient independence” to conduct his probe. Asked about jettisoning Mr. Mueller, some Republicans warned the move would be a mistake.Since his appointment by the Justice Department last month, Mr. Mueller has been quickly getting to work, hiring seasoned prosecutors and evaluating the investigative work that has taken place to date, according to people familiar with his operations.House Speaker       Paul Ryan       told reporters Tuesday: “I think the best advice is to let Robert Mueller do his job.”He added: “I think the best vindication for the president is to let this investigation to go on independently and thoroughly. That, to me, is the smartest thing to do, the best thing to do, and that’s what I think hopefully will happen.”Sen.       John McCain       (R., Ariz.), speaking at The Wall Street Journal’s CFO Network annual meeting on Tuesday, cautioned that firing Mr. Mueller “would be as explosive as any single act the president might take.”Senate Republican leader       Mitch McConnell       in a news conference said: “I have a lot of confidence in Bob Mueller.”As Mr. Mueller’s work has picked up, various allies of Mr. Trump have stepped forward and questioned whether he is needed.Mr. Gingrich said that a special counsel “can get out of control.”Mr. Ruddy, in his interview with PBS NewsHour on Monday, said that before taking the special counsel job, Mr. Mueller spoke to the president about possibly succeeding Mr. Comey as FBI director—a job Mr. Mueller had held for 12 years before Mr. Comey’s appointment in 2013. A White House official confirmed Monday that such a job interview took place.When offered the position of special counsel investigating an administration that had recently interviewed him for a job, Mr. Mueller should have recognized a conflict and declined, Mr. Ruddy said. A spokesman for Mr. Mueller declined to comment.—Natalie Andrews and Siobhan Hughes contributed to this article.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com and Aruna Viswanatha at Aruna.Viswanatha@wsj.com

content: RIO DE JANEIRO—Former Rio de Janeiro state Gov.       Sérgio Cabral       was sentenced to 14 years in prison Tuesday for corruption and money laundering, becoming one of the most high-profile Brazilian politicians yet convicted in the sprawling Car Wash probe.Judge       Sergio Moro       found Mr. Cabral guilty of receiving around 2.7 million Brazilian reais ($816,450) in bribes and laundering some of the proceeds. The money had been skimmed off an overpriced construction contract for a refinery built by state-owned oil company         Petróleo Brasileiro SA,       or Petrobras, on the outskirts of Rio.Mr. Cabral’s attorney said he plans to appeal but declined to specify on what grounds.Once considered a likely presidential candidate, Mr. Cabral rode the commodity boom to political stardom during his 2007-14 term, as Rio experienced a fleeting renaissance that culminated in its winning bid for the 2016 Olympics.With state coffers flush with cash from rising oil prices, Mr. Cabral attacked the city’s notorious crime problem by implementing a community policing program in favelas, or slums, long controlled by drug gangs. He propped up employment by drastically expanding the state’s payroll and spent billions of dollars on infrastructure projects, such as a new Metro line, whose costs, prosecutors say, have been inflated by corruption.As a result, Rio state is now in the throes of an epic fiscal crisis, unable to pay the salaries or pensions. After falling in 2012 to the lowest level in decades, violence has come roaring back, with more than 5,000 murders last year and 920 killings by police officers, in a state home to some 16.6 million people.“The failed situation of Rio de Janeiro state cannot be ignored, as the suffering of the population and civil servants, which despite being the result of many factors, also has its origins in the systematic graft by the ex-governor and his associates,” Judge Moro wrote in his ruling.Tuesday’s case is only the first to be ruled upon against Mr. Cabral, the son of a well-known music critic who rose from modest origins in Rio de Janeiro’s working-class north side.In addition to Car Wash, Mr. Cabral is the target of parallel investigations into graft from Rio’s state health-care system, infrastructure projects and public works ahead of the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Olympics.Altogether, prosecutors allege the ex-governor diverted more than $100 million from public coffers, stashing the proceeds in offshore bank accounts and laundering much of the money by purchasing luxury goods such as diamonds.In March, the Car Wash task force in Rio de Janeiro repatriated 250 million reais from foreign bank accounts allegedly controlled by Mr. Cabral’s “criminal organization,” prosecutors said. The money was handed over to the state government, which used it to pay the overdue salaries of 147,342 employees.“That represents just part of the money that has been apprehended, with still more believed to be hidden,” prosecutor       Leonardo Cardoso de Freitas       said at the time. “These numbers give an idea of how big the cost of corruption is in Brazil.”Write to Paul Kiernan at paul.kiernan@wsj.com
news_title: Brazil Judge Sentences Ex-Rio Governor to 14 Years in Corruption Case

content: Oil prices ended higher Tuesday ahead of data on U.S. oil stockpiles due to be released Wednesday.U.S. crude futures rose 38 cents, or 0.82%, to $46.46 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Brent, the global benchmark, rose 43 cents, or 0.89%, to $48.72 on ICE Futures Europe.Last week oil prices fell sharply after the U.S. Energy Information Administration reported that U.S. stockpiles rose for the first time in nine weeks—taking the market by surprise.Investors are betting that last week’s increase was a one-off, and that Wednesday’s data will show that inventories fell. Analysts surveyed by The Wall Street Journal are anticipating a 2.6- million-barrel decline.“We started seeing the buying come in off of expectation of stock draws,” said Ric Navy, senior vice president for energy futures at RJ O’Brien & Associates LLC.The American Petroleum Institute, an industry group, said late Tuesday that its own data for the week showed a 2.8-million-barrel increase in crude supplies, a 1.8-million-barrel rise in gasoline stocks and a 1.5-million-barrel decrease in distillate inventories, according to a market participant.Oil traded lower in the day after the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said it had produced more crude in May.OPEC said its output rose 1% to 32.14 million barrels a day in May, led by increases in Libya, Nigeria and Iraq, according to its closely watched monthly report.The output increases come even as the cartel is trying to convince market participants that its cuts are reducing the size of a glut that has weighed on the market for nearly three years.“It doesn’t sound good by any stretch of the imagination. It’s not good to see them adding barrels,” said       Bob Yawger,        director of the Futures Division of Mizuho Securities USA.OPEC and major non-U. S. producers such as Russia agreed to reduce their production by 1.8 million barrels a day starting in January. Even though the deal was recently extended to next March, investors’ faith has faded as analysts say U.S. shale producers have boosted output, slowing OPEC’s efforts and keeping the world awash with oil.Rising production in Nigeria and Libya has been anticipated, as those countries were exempted from the production-reduction pact.Saudi Arabia, OPEC’s biggest producer and the world’s biggest exporter, also raised its production slightly in May, according to secondary sources cited by OPEC.But Saudi Arabia’s energy minister said Sunday that he is confident that market rebalancing will soon gather steam. The country is looking to cut its shipments to key markets, including the U.S., where any increase in inventories can prompt a major selloff.The state-owned Saudi Arabian Oil Co. has been raising prices for U.S. customers and expects exports to the U.S. to fall to a nearly three-decade low in July. Seasonally, Saudi Arabia’s exports are lower over the summer when its domestic demand for power peaks.But some said the move won’t change much.“In itself it’s something that was expected, I think it would have had greater impact if it was done three months ago,” said Olivier Jakob at Switzerland-based consultancy Petromatrix.Gasoline futures rose 1.15 cents, or 0.77%, to $1.4995 a gallon. Diesel futures rose 2.23 cents, or 1.56%, to $1.4477 a gallon—Summer Said and Jenny W. Hsu contributed to this article.Write to Alison Sider at alison.sider@wsj.com and Sarah McFarlane at sarah.mcfarlane@wsj.com

content: Regarding “James Comey’s Passion Play” (Review & Outlook, June 9): Former FBI Director       James Comey       is a coward for failing to stand up to President Trump and former Attorney General Loretta Lynch. Anyone in the military, law enforcement, auditing, law or medicine at some point has to confront a supervisor and tell him he is wrong. When Mr. Trump said that Gen.       Michael Flynn       is “a good guy” and hoped Mr. Comey could “let this one go,” he should have smiled and said: “We don’t want to go there. We will work Flynn’s case as quickly as we can.”When Mr. Trump asked for loyalty, Mr. Comey could have said he would keep the president in the loop. When Attorney General Loretta Lynch told Mr. Comey to say that the       Hillary Clinton       investigation was to be described as a “matter,” Mr. Comey should have said that he would not do it. Instead he caved.Mr. Comey should have understood that his superior is a political novice, and instead of stabbing him in the back by leaking a memo, should have guided him into understanding the complex relationship between the president and FBI. The FBI is not independent and the president can fire the FBI director, but to do so risks precious political capital and invites a special counsel, which has happened.James Comey failed as a subordinate in supporting his boss’s boss. He deserved to be fired.O.S. MartinRichardson, TexasJames Comey disclosed that President Trump was not a target of the Russia probe. Far from obstructing Mr. Comey’s investigation, Mr. Trump encouraged him to ferret out any campaign staff who interacted inappropriately with Russians. It was Loretta Lynch who gave Mr. Comey an inappropriate order—to follow Democrat talking points in referring to the criminal investigation of Hillary Clinton, not as investigation, but nebulously as a “matter.” One wonders what she spoke about with a potential target of the investigation when she met secretly with       Bill Clinton       on the tarmac.Not since the Army-McCarthy hearings has a single media appearance done so much to dispel mass hysteria about Russians hiding under our beds.Richard A. CraneChicagoI had the opportunity to watch James Comey testify in front of the Senate Intelligence Committee. I saw a man who was honest, straightforward and just. Despite all that has occurred in the past few months, he kept his cool and stuck to the facts, giving the committee all the information that he could give.I am very proud to have had Mr. Comey serve as our FBI director. He is a true American patriot.Nameer BhattiBlue Bell, Pa.I believe President Trump was surprised by James Comey’s refusal to pledge loyalty. Isn’t that what Mr. Comey displayed toward Loretta Lynch? The FBI conducted a sham investigation of Hillary Clinton and her associates’ abuse of classified information. No grand jury was convened by the Justice Department. Mrs. Clinton wasn’t interviewed until very late in the game, and then not under oath and the interview wasn’t recorded. Mrs. Clinton’s Chief of Staff       Cheryl Mills       was given immunity for the contents of her laptop and allowed to serve as her former boss’s lawyer though she had handled emails that were the point of the “matter.”Mr. Trump could have reasonably expected the same courtesy as Mr. Comey had shown to President Obama, Loretta Lynch and Hillary Clinton.Francis G. KnipeTorrance, Calif.It is not clear to me how anyone can justify the head of the FBI leaking information. The actions of a company’s chief drive the actions of the organization. Mr. Comey’s actions effectively say to all of the FBI that it is OK to leak.Jim IkelerCincinnatiIf Mr. Comey’s backdoor approach to triggering the appointment of a special counsel to investigate the president or his advisers is honorable behavior in the swamp, do most of Washington’s many deep-state leakers of information (sometimes classified) deserve to be reclassified as heroes?Twenty-five-year-old federal contractor Reality Winner, described by friends and family as a passionate person, decided recently that the public deserved to know more about Russian military intelligence cyberattacks. She shared classified information directly with the media and now is in trouble with the Justice Department. She should have used a friend to serve as a document-release buffer.Please forgive us despicable simpletons for not understanding the mystifying ways of the Washington swamp ecosystem.Tom WestRaleigh, N.C.

content: Bail reconciles the competing interest of ensuring that an arrested person appears for the proceeding to determine guilt and the value that the person is presumed innocent (“Cash Bail, Staple of Courts, Is Fading,” page one, May 23). Opponents of bail inaccurately portray it as a means to restrain a person solely because he or she cannot afford the bail amount. Courts haven’t recognized a right to affordable bail, and any concerns regarding whether bail is “excessive” if the arrested person cannot raise the funds should be dismissed. The touchstone in determining whether bail is excessive under the Eighth Amendment isn’t what the arrested person can pay but rather the amount relative to an amount reasonably calculated to assure his or her appearance.The surety bail arrangement is effective in ensuring that an arrested person will appear at various proceedings. The agent often obtains collateral or indemnity from friends and family members to guarantee that if the arrested person fails to appear and the bond is forfeited, the agent and surety will have indemnity for the loss. This provides powerful financial incentive to see that the arrested person appears in court or is recovered promptly in the event of a default. The agent also monitors the arrested person to avoid a default and attempts to recover an arrested person who failed to appear. These systemic incentives are lacking in the case of a personal recognizance or an unsecured bond. Under other measures, the costs for monitoring and recovery are transferred from the arrested person to taxpayers.Robert J. DukeThe Surety & Fidelity Assn. of AmericaWashingtonKentucky eliminated bail bondsmen in 1976, and our pretrial release system has worked well for more than 40 years.Justice (Ret.) J. William GravesPaducah, Ky.

content: Converting natural gas into liquified natural gas and transporting it by sea has made gas available to many new regions (“Long a Promise, Gas Goes Global,” page one, June 7). However, the benefits of a more integrated global market don’t extend to all regions of the U.S. The Jones Act, which requires the use of American-built ships on domestic voyages, makes it prohibitively expensive to transport LNG to all domestic ports, but especially the noncontiguous regions of Hawaii, Alaska and Puerto Rico. Currently no Jones Act-eligible tankers are capable of carrying LNG. To transport LNG from a West Coast port such as Oregon to Hawaii would require building a much more expensive American ship. Repealing or reforming the Jones Act would give Americans access to improved transport infrastructure, allow greater energy production and relax excessive regulation without any cost to the federal budget.Em. Prof. Thomas GrennesNorth Carolina State UniversityRaleigh, N.C.

content: WASHINGTON—Sen.       Elizabeth Warren       said Tuesday that Senate Democrats are willing to pursue targeted changes for regulations affecting community banks and credit unions as Congress moves to review postcrisis financial regulations.But the Massachusetts Democrat, Congress’s leading critic of Wall Street, said she would stand fast against changing laws to roll back consumer protection or to help big banks.Ms. Warren’s remarks at The Wall Street Journal’s CFO Network Annual Meeting came a day after the Trump administration unveiled a road map for easing regulatory requirements for all types of financial institutions.“There are places where we should do targeted changes in laws and regulations to make sure community banks don’t have to endure regulations…for problems like disrupting the entire U.S. economy when they really don’t pose that kind of threat,” Ms. Warren said.While House Republicans and the Trump administration have unveiled plans to unwind various postcrisis financial regulations, many of them require legislative actions that are only possible with the support of at least some Senate Democrats. That gives leverage to senators like Ms. Warren who lead debates on regulating banks.“We can work together when you are not changing the law,” she said.The Trump administration’s report released Monday made recommendations that largely reflect financial industry’s wish lists, from easing capital and liquidity requirements to reducing regulatory exams such as “stress tests.”A section of the report was devoted to overhauling the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the independent agency Ms. Warren helped to create. The Treasury Department report described the CFPB as an “unaccountable” agency that has abused its authority and recommended steps to restrict its power.Ms. Warren said that polls have shown some 80% of the general public and 55% of the supporters of President Donald Trump wanted the agency left in the current state, if not made more powerful.Ms. Warren was particularly critical of House Republicans for passing a bill last week that she said included measures to roll back rules for large financial institutions to the point where they are weaker than regulations that existed before 2008.“I’ve got to say to a crowd like this everyone should be saying: No. No. No. No. No,” she said. “This ought to be one of the things that should unite all of us in saying we are not in favor of deregulation that puts the American taxpayer, and more importantly, the American economy, at greater risk.”Write to Yuka Hayashi at yuka.hayashi@wsj.com

content: Uber chief       Travis Kalanick’s       decision to take an indefinite leave of absence lands him in a very small camp of chief executives.A search of SEC filings over the past decade shows several dozen heads of publicly traded companies have taken a temporary leave because of illness—such as when United Airlines CEO       Oscar Munoz       suffered a heart attack in 2015 followed by a heart transplant in 2016. But only a handful of CEOs opted or were forced to take a break for nonmedical reasons.At least one company leader took a leave of absence because he was incarcerated, and then later returned.             Fog Cutter Capital Group Inc.,        FCCG -5.88%       owner of the Fatburger fast-food chain, announced a leave of absence for CEO Andrew Wiederhorn after he pleaded guilty to pension-law and income-tax felonies at a prior employer in June 2004.When Mr. Wiederhorn, the company’s co-founder, began serving his 18-month sentence in August 2004, he kept his board seat. The company also changed his title to chief strategic officer. His leave lasted until October 2005, company regulatory filings stated.Mr. Kalanick wrote in an email to Uber’s 12,000 employees on Tuesday that he would shift his responsibilities to his direct reports while he is away, stepping in only for major strategic decisions. The leave is necessary, the 40-year-old co-founder of the ride-hailing company said, “to become the leader that this company needs.” Mr. Kalanick is also grieving his mother, who died last month in a boating accident that also left his father seriously injured.Jeffrey Cohn,        managing director for global CEO succession planning at executive-recruitment firm DHR International, predicts Mr. Kalanick won’t return, even though Mr. Kalanick and his allies have voting control of the company.“It takes years to become a good leader,’’ Mr. Cohn said, adding that the CEO and fellow directors “will come to appreciate this fact during Travis’s leave of absence.’’If Mr. Kalanick does return, his CEO role will be different, said Scott Eblin, an author and executive coach to senior executives at Fortune 500 companies. Mr. Kalanick announced his leave as Uber released some of the results of an investigation into its workplace culture by former U.S. Attorney General       Eric Holder’s       law firm.The recommendations, which include shifting some of Mr. Kalanick’s responsibilities to other managers and holding senior executives more accountable for metrics such as addressing employee complaints and improving diversity, criticized Uber’s work culture for reinforcing bad behavior.“The company needs to grow up, and that’s what the recommendations are really about,” Mr. Eblin said. “Kalanick will have to be the chief cultural officer as well as the chief executive officer.”Appeared in the June 14, 2017, print edition as 'Few CEOs Ever Take a Leave for Nonmedical Reasons.'

content: WASHINGTON—The Trump administration’s new plan for bank oversight is raising industry expectations that a postcrisis era of heightened regulation is over.A report from the Treasury Department, released Monday, contains dozens of specific recommendations that can be executed by financial regulators.Bankers and analysts said they expect the proposal will be a catalyst for changes to the Wall Street rule book once President       Donald Trump’s       banking-oversight nominees are confirmed.The report shows a desire by officials to take a lighter touch after years of new restrictions adopted in response to the 2008 financial crisis and the severe recession that followed.It fleshes out statements in recent months by Mr. Trump and Treasury Secretary       Steven Mnuchin,        a former banker who has said the administration won’t throw out bank rules wholesale, but that many aspects of the current regulatory regime are too restrictive.“The greatest impact would be it would allow management and our board to go back to running and planning for the future of the company, as opposed to spending lots of mandated, repetitive hours reviewing and updating regulatory matters,”       William Demchak,        chief executive of             PNC Financial Services Group Inc.,       said in an interview.He added that some changes, such as narrowing the scope of so-called liquidity rules, could free up the Pittsburgh-based firm to do more lending.Many of the Treasury’s proposed changes dovetail with bankers’ previous recommendations, for instance in             J.P. Morgan Chase                   & Co. Chief Executive       James Dimon’s       shareholder letter earlier this year.“The road ahead remains long given the sluggish pace of personnel shifts, but these recommendations should be viewed as an undeniably positive policy signal for banks” said       Isaac Boltansky,        an analyst with Compass Point Research & Trading LLC, in a note to clients.Craig Phillips,        the counselor to the U.S. Treasury secretary who played a central role in drafting the report, presented the recommendations to a conference hosted by two bank trade groups Tuesday.“This is not a plan to help banks,” but rather ideas meant to boost economic growth, he said. “There is a lot to do with regulatory overlap, fragmentation and duplication. This is one of the biggest issues,” he added.Mr. Phillips told the assembled crowd to expect additional reports on other topics including unwinding failed firms, designating companies systemically important, nonbank financial services and markets oversight.Liberal lawmakers and advocacy groups said the recommendations would undermine protections against fraud and excessive risk-taking. Sen.       Sherrod Brown       of Ohio, the top Democrat on the Senate Banking Committee, said that of roughly 300 entities that the Treasury Department said it consulted for the report, 244 came from the banking industry. The report says officials met with the banks of all sizes as well as consumer groups and others.“Too many hardworking Americans still haven’t fully recovered from the financial crisis, and Washington should be focused on protecting them by holding Wall Street accountable, not doing its bidding,” Mr. Brown said in a news release Monday.Senate Banking Committee Chairman       Mike Crapo       (R., Idaho) in a statement Tuesday welcomed “reasonable and meaningful recommendations to the existing, and all too often, one-size-fits-all regulatory landscape.”Mr. Crapo appeared at the banking conference and said he believed some of the report’s recommendations requiring congressional approval could win bipartisan support, especially those affecting small and medium-size banks.Mr. Crapo also said he was open to a new idea raised in the Treasury’s report: granting more power to the Financial Stability Oversight Council. The council was created by the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial overhaul and empowered to watch over the stability of the financial system.The council includes the most powerful U.S. economic officials: the Treasury secretary, the chair of the Federal Reserve, and other top regulators.Republicans for years have talked about hamstringing or abolishing the council. The Treasury report said Congress should grant it the power to assign a “lead regulator” to make decisions about policy matters involving multiple federal agencies.Mr. Mnuchin has already used his position as chair of the council to push regulators to begin a review of the Volcker rule, a Dodd-Frank provision banning banks from certain types of trading, according to people familiar with the matter. That rule is enforced by five regulatory agencies, all of which have seats on the council.“I don’t like to generally consolidate even more power in such a powerful entity,” Mr. Crapo said. “However, we are running into situations where the law gives up to five agencies the authority to administer one statute and they can’t even get a consistent rule.”Treasury’s suggestion “might be the right way to approach it,” he said.—Andrew Ackerman and Rachel Witkowski contributed to this article.Write to Ryan Tracy at ryan.tracy@wsj.comAppeared in the June 14, 2017, print edition as 'Bank Plan Heralds End Of Crisis Era.'
news_title: Trump Administration’s Bank Plan Heralds End of Crisis Era

content: The dollar wavered Tuesday as the Federal Reserve began its latest policy meeting.The WSJ Dollar Index, which measures the U.S. currency against 16 others, was down 0.1% to 88.31.The Fed is widely expected to raise its benchmark interest-rate by a quarter percentage when it concludes its meeting Wednesday.Investors will focus on the Fed’s statement and post-meeting press conference, which could offer clues on the central bank’s plans for future rate-increases and shrinking its balance sheet.“We expect a “dovish hike”—raising rates but signaling a pause perhaps until year-end—to weigh further on the U.S. dollar,” said analysts at Scotiabank in a research note.Recent weakness in U.S. inflation data has raised concerns that the U.S. economy is slowing, which some investors believe dulls the Fed’s case for tightening policy. Higher rates typically support the dollar by making U.S. assets more attractive to yield-seeking investors.The Bank of England, Bank of Japan and Swiss National Bank also hold policy meetings this week.The British pound recovered from a three-day selloff, rising 0.7% against the dollar, after data showed U.K. inflation rose in May. The British currency has tumbled since Prime Minister       Theresa May’s       Conservative Party lost its majority in last Thursday’s election, fueling uncertainty over the path of U.K. politics and its looming Brexit negotiations.The Canadian dollar jumped 0.6% against the U.S. currency after upbeat comments from central bank officials fueled speculation that the Bank of Canada could raise interest rates.Write to Chelsey Dulaney at Chelsey.Dulaney@wsj.com

content: Boeing Co.        BA 1.27%       said it is removing a layer of executives from its defense business this year in response to government criticism that slow decision making has hurt its chances of winning big contracts from the Pentagon.The world’s second-largest defense contractor by revenues is chasing a big win to maintain its production lines and engineering workforce, having suffered sobering losses such as its failed pursuit in 2015 to build the new Air Force B-21 bomber.Leanne Caret,        president of Boeing Defense, Space & Security, said in an interview that the restructuring announced Tuesday wasn’t driven by a particular contract loss, but the company recognized it couldn’t afford to stand still as rivals including             Lockheed Martin Corp.        LMT 1.35%      ,             Northrop Grumman Corp.       and             Raytheon Co.        RTN 0.61%       returned to growth on the back of winning big long-term contracts.Boeing’s defense revenues have fallen over the past three years, but it’s been more profitable than its commercial jetliner business and expansion is central to efforts to boost company margins to the midteens from around 10% at present.The company has already cut jobs and moved the defense unit’s headquarters close to the Pentagon from its longtime home in St. Louis, Mo. She said feedback from the Defense Department indicated the need for Boeing to become more agile.It’s cutting the number of management layers to six or less, with more program leaders reporting direct to the president of the division, and it will cut or downgrade around 50 executive positions.“There was the culmination of not winning,” Ms. Caret said, with frustration at the absence of a big new program that could sustain the business for years or even decades.For instance, Boeing and partner Lockheed Martin were ultimately undercut on price by Northrop in the B-21 contest. It’s a program expected to cost $80 billion which could sustain the winner for more than a decade.Like its rivals, Boeing has found the Pentagon’s selection process for big new contracts has become more fickle. Proposal documents can run to thousands of pages, and competing offerings often have only tiny differences in their technical merits.“Then it’s a price competition,” said Ms. Caret, with a premium placed on companies that can quickly respond to any changes required by the Pentagon.The defense unit will be restructured around four smaller entities covering military aircraft, rotorcraft, autonomous systems and space and missile systems.Ms. Caret said she expected the changes to make Boeing more competitive in three big ongoing contests for fleets of new Air Force training and surveillance jets, as well as replacing land-based nuclear missiles. “This is affecting the executive ranks, not the engineers and technicians on the floor,” she said.The restructuring is also directed at longer-term opportunities such as revamping military helicopters and developing new unmanned undersea vehicles for the Navy.While there’s concern about Boeing’s ability to win new weapons’ platforms, the existing business has outperformed management expectations over the past year, potentially preserving two combat jet lines that had been earmarked for potential closure by the end of the decade.Sales still dipped 3% in 2016 to $29.5 billion last year, some 31% of group revenue, though the backlog of new business climbed to $63 billion at the end of the first quarter, more than a third of it from overseas customers. Boeing said it picked up a potential $50 billion in deals during President       Donald Trump’s       recent state visit to Saudi Arabia.Write to Doug Cameron at doug.cameron@wsj.com

content: Data center landlord             Digital Realty                   Trust’s deal to merge with             DuPont Fabros Technology Inc.        DFT -0.44%       in a stock-for-stock transaction that would value the combined company at roughly $34 billion casts new light on the booming business of data-center development.Data center landlords have seen a rise in demand from tenants that include technology companies and telecommunication firms, with rising rents supported by a limited supply of data centers.E-commerce and the increased usage of mobile data among consumers are fueling strong growth, said Fitch Ratings in a research note.The deal will strengthen Digital Realty’s existing portfolio in key markets such as Northern Virginia, Chicago and Silicon Valley and help grow Digital Realty’s exposure to cloud service providers and enhance its top-line growth.Digital Realty has 145 properties across 33 global metropolitan areas.Write to Esther Fung at esther.fung@wsj.com

content: Google parent             Alphabet Inc.        GOOGL 0.59%       retired its self-driving prototype dubbed the “Firefly,” a tiny test car with no steering wheel or pedals, to focus on building its self-driving technology into mass-produced vehicles.The vehicle, built in collaboration with Detroit-based auto supplier Roush Industries, started hitting roads in a testing capacity in 2014, with a capped speed of 25 miles an hour. It became iconic as autonomous-car development heated up and a symbol of Silicon Valley’s assault on the automotive industry.The move confirms that Alphabet’s driverless-car unit Waymo has come to terms with the high regulatory and societal hurdles of selling vehicles without traditional controls. Instead, Waymo said it is focused on automating commercially available cars—like the hundreds of Pacifica minivans from             Fiat Chrysler Automobiles                   NV it is modifying—which will enable it “to bring fully self-driving technology to more people, more quickly.”Waymo has advocated cars without traditional controls, arguing that taking human drivers entirely out of the process is safer than asking them to take control on the fly. To help fulfill that vision, Waymo in 2014 debuted the Firefly, a two-seat concept car with few controls other than “Stop” and “Go” buttons.Firefly vehicles have helped Waymo amass more than 3 million miles in autonomous testing over the past three years, including a blind man’s ride around an Austin, Texas, neighborhood in October 2015 that Waymo says was the first time a car drove itself on U.S. roads without controls or a human backup.Regulators, however, have balked at the idea of cars without traditional controls. Federal rules require cars to have features like steering wheels.Waymo Chief Executive       John Krafcik       has said the company has lobbied regulators to allow cars without such controls, but meanwhile, Waymo would install its technology in conventional vehicles. “We’re not in the business of making better cars, we’re in the business of making better drivers,” he told reporters in December.Separately on Tuesday,             Apple Inc.       Chief Executive       Tim Cook       told Bloomberg News that the company has scrapped plans to build its own self-driving cars and instead is focused on developing the underlying technology to automate vehicles.Write to Jack Nicas at jack.nicas@wsj.com
news_title: Google Parent Retires ‘Firefly’ Self-Driving Prototype

content: Hexagon        HXGBY 0.03%       AB has held talks on a possible sale to a U.S. or European rival that could value the industrial-technology company at some $20 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.The talks between Hexagon and potential buyers are at an early stage and the company, one of Sweden’s biggest, may ultimately decide not to pursue a sale.Two factors are pushing the company to consider a deal, the people said: an insider-trading case against its chief executive, and the ill-health of its largest shareholder. In March, Hexagon Chief Executive       Ola Rollén       was indicted on insider-trading charges related to an outside investment. The company said it continues to support Mr. Rollén, who denies wrongdoing, and he remains CEO. Meanwhile, Melker Schörling, whose company is Hexagon’s largest shareholder, recently stepped down as chairman of Hexagon due to health issues. As of May 31, Melker Schörling AB owned more than 25% of Hexagon’s stock and nearly half its voting rights.Should there be a sale, it would be substantial: Stockholm-based Hexagon had €3.15 billion ($3.5 billion) in revenue last year and sports a market value of about 130 billion Swedish kronor ($15 billion).The company develops information-technology tools used by industrial companies to boost productivity and quality. Its technology has been used to guide construction of New York City’s One World Trade Center and to improve vehicle assembly at             Volkswagen AG      , according to Hexagon’s website.Big industrial companies on both sides of the Atlantic have been trying to position themselves as more technology-oriented and digitize their operations. That could make Hexagon attractive to a number of large industrial concerns.Industrial technology has been a hot area for mergers and acquisitions of late. Earlier this year, Germany’s             Siemens AG       bought industrial-software provider Mentor Graphics Corp. for more than $4 billion. Last year,             Honeywell International Inc.       bought supply-chain and warehouse-automation company Intelligrated Inc. for $1.5 billion. Honeywell’s new CEO       Darius Adamczyk       has said he wants the company to focus more on software.Hexagon wouldn’t come cheap. It trades at a high-teens multiple of enterprise value to earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, and may not agree to a sale if a big enough bid doesn’t materialize.The company has about 17,000 employees in 50 countries. Half of its sales come from its so-called geospatial enterprise solutions business, which makes sensors and software for infrastructure and construction projects and caters to mining, agriculture and public-safety customers. The other half is derived from Hexagon’s industrial enterprise solutions business, which helps clients with measurement and quality inspection and makes software used to design, construct and operate industrial plants and offshore facilities.Mr. Rollén has served as president and CEO of Hexagon since 2000, and during his tenure the company’s value has soared. His trial is expected this fall.Write to Dana Mattioli at dana.mattioli@wsj.com and Dana Cimilluca at dana.cimilluca@wsj.comAppeared in the June 14, 2017, print edition as 'Sweden’s Hexagon Courts Bidders.'
news_title: Sweden’s Hexagon Holds Early-Stage Talks With Rivals on Possible Sale

content: Markets aren’t ready for the Federal Reserve to start shrinking its big asset portfolio later this year, according to a recent survey by a policy research firm.Fed officials in May outlined a proposed approach that would let increasing amounts of bonds mature over time, without reinvesting the proceeds. They could announce Wednesday, after a two-day policy meeting, that they have adopted the plan and give new details of how it would work.But the Fed’s plans are only partly priced into Treasury and mortgage-bond markets, according to most of the respondents to a survey of 107 market participants by MacroPolicy Perspectives LLC. The group polled included 21 of the 53 firms the Fed reaches in its surveys of bond brokers and asset managers.About 50% said the plans weren’t at all priced into stocks, and 42% said they weren’t at all priced into credit markets.“Hardly anyone in our survey said it’s fully priced into any market,” said Laura Rosner, senior economist at MacroPolicy Perspectives in New York and a former senior economist at BNP Paribas SA, a French bank.That sets up the risk of an adverse market reaction if the Fed doesn’t successfully communicate its policy plans before it begins the process.These implications stem from the firm’s first quarterly survey of market participants since it was formed this year by       Julia Coronado,        a former chief U.S. economist at BNP. The poll was designed to mimic the New York Fed surveys of bond brokers and investors ahead of Fed policy meetings, while capturing a broader range of noneconomist views, Ms. Rosner said.The survey was conducted June 2-8. MacroPolicy Perspectives plans to conduct similar polls quarterly, ahead of Fed meetings that are scheduled to be followed by press conferences.Some 54% of respondents said they believe the Fed will announce in September when it plans to start reducing its holdings, while 31% said the announcement likely would come in December.Just 6% expected the Fed to make changes this week to its current policy of reinvesting proceeds from maturing Treasury and mortgage bonds into new bonds.In a Wall Street Journal survey in May, most economists predicted the Fed would start unwinding the portfolio before year-end. Some 40% said the Fed would take action on the balance sheet in December, and another 18% said the Fed would move sooner than December.The central bank has taken pains to clarify it will shrink its $4.5 trillion holdings, or balance sheet, very gradually, to avoid prompting investors to dump bonds en masse.Under the plan being considered, the Fed would set caps on the amount of bonds it allowed to mature per month, and raise them each quarter. The Fed hasn’t said what those limits would be.The survey found little consensus about the likely levels of the caps when they are fully phased in. Nearly a third of respondents, 30.5%, weren’t sure what the final Treasury caps would be. Of those who had an opinion, the median response was $30 billon.The Fed hasn’t said how big the portfolio is likely to be by the end of the process. Most survey respondents expected a $2 trillion to $2.9 trillion Fed balance sheet when the Fed is finished. But a large subset of noneconomists said they thought it could end up at $1 trillion to $1.9 trillion.On borrowing costs, nearly all, 97%, of the survey respondents expected the Fed to lift its benchmark federal-funds rate Wednesday.The economists generally expected more rate increases through next year than the noneconomists.The economists predicted the Fed would raise rates three times this year, in quarter-percentage-point increments, and three times next year, in line with Fed officials’ March projections. Noneconomists’ median forecast was for three such moves this year, but just 1½ next year.The Fed has convinced investors it will raise rates this week, “but now they need to work really hard to push up the probability of more hikes after the June meeting,” said Torsten Slok, chief economist at             Deutsche Bank AG      . While the Fed has penciled in three rate increases for 2017 and three next year, “the market just doesn’t believe” it, he said.Write to Katy Burne at katy.burne@wsj.com
news_title: Survey Shows Fed Balance-Sheet Reduction Not Priced Into Markets

content: OAKLAND, Calif.—Steve Kerr ran into Stephen Curry hours after the Golden State Warriors won the NBA championship on Monday night. His shirt was soaked in champagne. His shorts were stained with cigar ash. Kerr was impressed.“You already got a stogie?” he said.There was nobody on the Warriors, not even Kevin Durant, who deserved that stogie more than Curry. It has somehow become overlooked, but this championship team primed to become a dynasty wouldn’t exist if it weren’t for Curry. He’s still the player who makes the Warriors make sense.Curry was on the Warriors before the owners bought the team, before the executives built the team and before Kerr coached the team. He was on the Warriors before anyone in the locker room on Monday night played for that team. He was on the Warriors before Klay Thompson, before Draymond Green and long before Durant. They were only there because he was there first.But something unusual happened to Curry this season. The league’s reigning most valuable player became undervalued.There were times this season, especially in the playoffs and even in the Finals, when he made people remember that nothing in sports is more exciting than Curry seizing control of a game. It’s the thrill of watching a genius at work. But he wasn’t as magical this year as he was last year, and there were other players, even on his own team, who commanded more attention on a nightly basis. And yet this year’s Warriors were better than last year’s Warriors for a simple reason. Curry’s lack of ego allowed them to be.“When the lead singer in the band is the most humble, how can the guitarist act like he’s better than anybody else?” said Bob Myers, the team’s president of basketball operations. “That’s what makes us tick in a lot of ways.”Golden State’s delegation that pitched Durant last summer, after their 73-win season was spoiled in the Finals by the Cleveland Cavaliers, included owners, executives, coaches and the four other players in the small-ball lineup that all but won Game 5 on Monday night. Nobody in that room, though, was as important as Curry.The obvious question when they arrived was if the players—and one player in particular—really wanted Durant on their team. It seemed like adding truffles to foie gras. What they had was rich enough already. They didn’t need him. So why did they want him?It’s hard now to remember the heights that Curry had reached then. He was the league’s unanimous most valuable player. There wasn’t a single voter who believed anyone else in the NBA had a better season. There wasn’t even a talking head on television who argued otherwise. That’s how obvious it was. Curry inspired consensus among people who are paid to be contrarian.What he did will go down as one of the greatest individual seasons for one of the greatest teams of all time. And not long afterward he flew across the country to make sure it would never happen again. The meeting between Durant and the Warriors may have changed the next several years of the NBA, but the most remarkable thing about the meeting is that it happened in the first place.Curry wanted Durant as his teammate, he explained in a text message, because he wanted to win championships. Curry got what he wanted. Then he got what he really wanted.“The pursuit of Kevin says it all,” Myers said. “It’s all about winning, and it’s all about team. Unfortunately, that stands out in today’s era. But it does. In an era when your individual success is something put above your team’s, I don’t think he subscribes to that.”Curry’s willingness to make room for Durant wasn’t the only reason the Warriors could sign him. It also helped that Curry was a bargain himself. His contract was a four-year deal worth $44 million—less than eight players in the NBA Finals—while his next contract will almost certainly be a five-year deal worth more than $200 million.But it was his discount that let the Warriors keep Green and Thompson and sign Durant last summer. They could afford four stars because one of them wasn’t paid like a star. Curry was still paid like a Plumlee brother.Durant moving to the Bay Area meant things were going to be different for Curry. There were the big things, like Curry’s scoring average (30.1 to 25.3 points per game) and his MVP votes (all 131 last season to likely 0 this season), but also the small things behind the scenes.Curry usually shoots on a specific hoop after Golden State practices. Durant migrated there after several months. Before long they were competing with each other and making each other better. By the Finals, Curry and Durant’s shooting contests were a sight to behold.Their play on the court followed the same progression. First they learned to share a basket. Then they began pushing each other and playing better together. By the Finals, Curry and Durant were a sight to behold.Durant, the MVP of the Finals, averaged 35.2 points, 8.4 rebounds and 5.4 assists per game. Curry averaged 26.8 points, 9.4 assists and 8 rebounds per game. They each shot better with the other on the court. But it was in the clinching Game 5 when they were both at their best playing off each other in pick-and-rolls, because it turns out that pick-and-rolls with Curry and Durant are hard for human beings to defend.That’s why the single biggest strategic adjustment after Golden State’s only playoff loss was unleashing Curry to be more aggressive. In the first four Finals games, Curry averaged 294 dribbles, according to the NBA’s tracking data. In Game 5, he dribbled 495 times. He also had 10 assists and even five secondary assists. The Warriors’ most reliable plays started with the ball in Curry’s hands. He had to be selfish to be selfless.Durant understood by then why Golden State executives say the team’s culture was shaped by Curry. He’d become familiar with his quiet confidence. He appreciated what Curry had surrendered for Durant to be there. “It isn’t a facade,” he said. “He really is like that.”While the playoffs revealed why the Warriors wanted Durant, they also showed how much they still needed Curry. Golden State was 19.1 points per 100 possessions better than opponents with Curry and 3.2 points worse than opponents without Curry. With him, they were the Warriors. Without him, they’re the New York Knicks.That’s why it wasn’t a surprise the way Durant chose to celebrate his first championship. He congratulated LeBron James. He hugged his mom. And then he went searching for Stephen Curry.Write to Ben Cohen at ben.cohen@wsj.com
news_title: The NBA Dynasty Built Around Stephen Curry
keywords: basketball,curry,golden state warriors,kevin durant,nba,nba finals,steph curry,stephen curry,Golden State Warriors,sports,recreation,routine general news

content: A corporate dispute over a price-discount program for diabetes patients taking             Eli Lilly        LLY 0.63%       & Co.’s insulin has resulted in an industry middleman’s exit from the deal—the latest sign of discord among players in a prescription-drug supply chain facing criticism for high prices.Blink Health LLC, a provider of consumer price discounts for prescription drugs, said it has terminated its relationship with             Express Scripts        ESRX -0.96%       Holding Co., a pharmacy-benefit manager that helped arrange the new price break for Lilly’s insulin.Blink Health continues to offer the discount program at participating pharmacies in partnership with Lilly, Blink Health Chief Executive       Geoffrey Chaiken       said in an interview Tuesday. He said he couldn’t discuss specific reasons for the termination of the agreement with Express Scripts, which was recent.“We’ve built a business model where we are the agents of the patient and we have a responsibility to those patients to get them the lowest prices possible, and we only want to work with folks that are aligned with those values,” Mr. Chaiken said.An Express Scripts spokesman said the company disagreed with Mr. Chaiken’s assertion and that Express Script’s “entire business and mission are predicated upon lowering the price of medicine.”The Express Scripts spokesman said Blink Health “asked to terminate their agreement with us after they failed to live up to the contractual agreements they had struck with us. We agreed to allow the agreement to be terminated.” Express Scripts, which administers prescription coverage on behalf of employers and insurers, arranged with Lilly to extend the discounts through Blink until the end of this year, “unless Blink elects to terminate the Lilly discounts sooner,” the Express Scripts spokesman said.An Eli Lilly spokesman said the company’s insulin remains available at the same discounts through Blink Health and declined to comment on the Blink-Express Scripts dispute.Lilly, Express Scripts and Blink Health touted the insulin discount program as a partnership when it was announced in December. The program was designed for uninsured patients and others paying for insulin largely out-of-pocket, such as those with high deductible health-insurance plans. The program offers discounts of up to 40% off the list prices of the insulins Humalog, Humulin and Basaglar. Patients receive the discounts through Blink Health’s mobile and web applications and take them to participating pharmacies to get their insulin.Express Scripts said in December it negotiated the insulin discounts on behalf of Blink Health.Earlier this year, in a move independent of the insulin deal,             Walgreens Boots Alliance                   pharmacies dropped out of Blink Health’s network. Blink Health still has more than 57,000 participating pharmacies where patients can get the Blink discounts on Lilly’s insulin and other drugs, Mr. Chaiken said.As criticism of drug prices mounts, industry players have become increasingly willing to point fingers at each other over who is most to blame. Drug companies and others have accused pharmacy-benefit managers such as Express Scripts of not passing along to consumers the discounts they negotiate with drugmakers. PBMs say they help reduce drug costs, and blame manufacturers for raising list prices.Last year, health insurer             Anthem Inc.sued Express Scripts for about $15 billion in damages, alleging that the PBM violated their contract through excessive drug charges and failures in its operations. Express Scripts has denied the allegations; the suit is pending.Write to Peter Loftus at peter.loftus@wsj.com

content: As office tenants go, the Federal Bureau of Investigation ranks high on the list.That is the takeaway from the expected sale in the coming months of a Salt Lake City office building that is 100% occupied by an FBI field office. Its owner, an entity named KDC MLH SLC Venture LLC, has hired JLL to sell it, according to a listing by the real estate services firm.The 170,000 square foot building is expected to fetch as much as $90 million, according to market experts familiar with the listing. At $529 a square foot, that would make it one of the most expensive office buildings sold in the Salt Lake City region in recent years.The JLL listing describes the property, 5425 Amelia Earhart Drive, as a “mission-critical” facility. The deal “represents a rare opportunity to acquire a highly-specialized single-tenant building backed by the credit of the United States government,” the listing states.But the listing raises the question of what checks are in place to make sure an inappropriate buyer—say a mobster or a hostile foreign government—doesn’t control such a sensitive facility.The lease between the owner and the federal government—through the General Services Administration—contains no restrictions on who may purchase the building, according to a GSA spokesman. But under the lease, “the federal government has the right to review and recognize the new owner as an entity that can legally hold a federal government contract,” the spokesman said in an email.Steven Buss, the JLL managing director overseeing the sale, said his firm and the seller will be sensitive to the government’s concerns. “No one is interested in a situation where the government is surprised who it is,” he said.At the same time, potential buyers will likely be self-selecting, Mr. Buss said.“You’re not interested in being the landlord for a federal government tenant or agency that is not interested in having you as the owner,” he said.Write to Peter Grant at peter.grant@wsj.com
news_title: Landlord Puts FBI Building in Salt Lake City Up For Sale
